thread.title: Asian Bench Press Championship: Oman sub-junior, junior teams emerge champions
thread.title_full: Asian Bench Press Championship: Oman sub-junior, junior teams emerge champions

author: muscatdaily@apexmedia.co.om (Muscat Daily News)
title: Asian Bench Press Championship: Oman sub-junior, junior teams emerge champions
text:
Follow us on Asian Bench Press Championship: Oman sub-junior, junior teams emerge champions The Omani lifters with H E Sheikh Saad al Saadi, the Minister of Sports Affairs, at the awards ceremony on Monday Muscat Daily staff writer October 06, 2015 
Oman's sub-junior and junior lifters cornered glory as they were crowned overall champions in their respective categories on the concluding day of the Asian Bench Press Championship at the Sultan Qaboos Sports Complex on Monday. 
The teams were honoured at a gala prize distribution ceremony by H E Sheikh Saad al Saadi, the Minister of Sports Affairs, at Majan Hotel on Monday night. 
The host nation rounded off its campaign with a silver and a bronze on the final day of the five-day championship. Qais al Hasani lifted 150kg to claim the silver in the -120kg junior category, while Idris al Obaidani fetched the final medal for the sultanate with a bronze win in the 120kg sub-junior event with a lift of 70kg. 
Oman coach Ahmed al Hasani with the sub-junior and junior trophies 
The two medals helped Oman finish with a total of 13 medals that included four gold, four silver and five bronze. 
Speaking to Muscat Daily, Ahmed al Hasani, the Oman coach, said, “I am delighted with the results as it proves that we have a strong foundation. The two overall titles in the sub-junior and junior categories are testimony to the hard work put in by the lifters. We have a good future and I thank the Oman Committee for Powerlifting and the sports ministry for their support.” 
He added, “All my sub-junior and junior lifters were among medals. Only Musab al Hashmi, who was part of my junior team, was not among medals as he was forced out due to injury.” 
Of the four gold medals that Oman won, three were picked up by the sub-junior and junior lifters, while Yahya al Kiyumi won the title in the open class. 
Qais al Hasani (left) and Idris al Obaidani (V K Shafeer/Muscat Daily) 
Al Khatab al Auladthani and Fahad al Nadabi won the gold in the sub-junior section, while Omar al Zakwani picked up the junior category title. 
Expectedly, Al Khatab was adjudged the best lifter in the sub-junior section and Omar was named the best in the junior category at the awards ceremony. 
Iran finished runner-up behind the hosts in the sub-junior overall rankings, while Iraq took the third spot. In the junior category, Japan followed Oman in the second spot, while Iraq came third. 
In the open class, Oman was placed third and the title went to Iran, with Kazakhstan finishing runner-up. 
Indian lifters dominated the women's event, winning the overall titles in the open and sub-junior categories, while Pakistan took the junior honours. 
Saud al Khanjari, the director of the championship, later awarded top officials of the Asian Powerlifting Federation at a ceremony. 
Other overall men's rankings: Master 1: 1 Iran, 2 India, 3 Iraq; Master 2: 1 India, 2 Japan, 3 Iran; Master 3: 1 Pakistan, Japan, Iran; Master 4 winner: Iraq. Similar content
